Award.AwardTitle: Paleoenvironmental and Paleoclimatic Analysis of the Beacon Supergroup, Beardmore Glacier Area, Central Transantarctic Mountains, Antarctica
Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual Merit:
This proposal will study the diversity, abundance, and tiering patterns of ichnofossils in continental and marine deposits of the Beacon Supergroup in the Beardmore Glacier Area (BGA). The PIs will focus on continental strata that contain a variety of ichnofossils and paleosols. Ichnofossils will be evaluated for their architectural and surficial morphologies, and will be compared to modern and ancient traces to interpret the tracemaker behavior and paleoenvironmental setting. Distribution of ichnofossils within these units may indicate the effect of lateral variability of pedogenesis, the magnitude and frequency of depositional events, and the amount of moisture within the sediment, as well as the effects of climate change. The paleoclimatic significance of ichnofossils will be determined by comparing the burrow size, occurrence, tiering, and pedogenic significance of ichnofossils in measured sections of stratigraphic units deposited during global warming and cooling episodes. Comparisons will be made between BGA formations to stratigraphically equivalent rocks deposited at low paleolatitudes with previously determined paleoclimatic settings. The objectives of this project are to address two major questions: what differences existed in ichnodiversity, abundance, and tiering in marine and continental deposits between high- and low-paleolatitudes, and was there a dearth of habitat usage in continental deposits during the late Paleozoic and Mesozoic, particularly in fluvial and lacustrine environments compared to the habitat usage in the marine realm at that time?

Broader impacts:
This study will enhance the ability to interpret paleoenvironments to the subenvironmental scale, understand the evolution of soil biota and ecosystems at high paleolatitudes, determine the role of organisms in soil formation at high paleolatitudes, explore the effects of climate change on the body size and diversity of organisms in the soil communities, and develop new tools to interpret paleoclimate in high latitudes. There is a strong education component associated with this proposal.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Goals for our Beardmore Glacier region (BGR) research project were to determine the: (1) representative sediment textures and structures (facies) and trace fossil—proxies for microbes, plants, and animals as burrows, tracks, trails, nests, rooting patterns—content of the Permian-Triassic (P-Tr; 280 to 210 million year old) rock formations (fms) in the Beacon Supergroup; (2) physicochemical factors—sediment accumulation rate, groundwater profile, depositional energy, temperature, salinity, water oxygen content—of the ancient environments as recorded by trace fossils; (3) differences in trace fossil characteristics of marine and continental deposits between high and low paleolatitude; (4) effect of the P-Tr mass extinction (ME) on continental (terrestrial and freshwater) organisms as recorded by trace fossils; (5) evidence for change in facies, stacking pattern, and provenance (i.e., place of origin of sediment) across the P-Tr boundary and what drove those changes; and (6) validity of the hypothesis that the trace fossil diversity of ancient high latitude continental environments of Antarctica was greater than the low latitude ancient environments represented in the United States southwest during that same period of time.

Success was achieved for all five goals as our study produced detailed evidence for abundant and diverse trace fossils in the Mackellar, Buckley, and Fremouw fms that record ancient environments with distinct physicochemical signatures, which include significant paleontologic and sedimentologic discoveries. (1) Sedimentologic and trace fossil evidence in the Mackellar Formation (Fm) suggests the presence of basinal, deltaic, and prodeltaic environments of an epicontinental sea, where brackish-water marine salinities existed due to freshwater mixing with marine water. Previous interpretations thought that these rocks represented a lacustrine (i.e., lake) environment. (2) We discovered the first evidence of horseshoe crabs in Antarctica as preserved by trackways in the Buckley and Fremouw fms. Horseshoe crab trackways indicate that they lived in freshwater rivers and lakes in the P-Tr and survived the P-Tr ME. These discoveries record the oldest true freshwater occurrence of horseshoe crabs in the world, including the most southern known extent of horseshoe crab fossil evidence in the rock record. (3) Trace fossils are more abundant and more diverse in P-Tr fms of Antarctica than previously suggested based on past work. This is important in that the greenhouse climate conditions made Antarctica pleasant and livable for many plant and animal species than previously thought. (4) Trace fossils show fewer losses in diversity across the P-Tr ME boundary (PTB), which was the greatest loss of diversity—about 95%—recorded by any ME on Earth. In fact, we found an apparent increase in terrestrial (vertebrate) diversity across the PTB based on trace fossils. (5) Facies, ichnofossils, and paleosols record a hydroclimate shift across the PTB, meaning that the environments across this boundary became better drained due to warmer climates, which allowed a greater range of habitats to exist to support a greater diversity of plants and animals to exist in this part of Antarctica. (6) Ancient high latitude continental environments of Antarctica did not have a higher diversity of trace fossils compared to the ancient low latitude environments represented in the United States southwest during that same period of time. Previous researchers suggest that the high latitude Antarctic environments had more diverse life, but our ongoing research in P-Tr rocks in the United States southwest still has much higher diversity, despite our new discoveries in Antarctica. Our results support the theory that the diversity of life evolves at low latitude and then migrates to high latitude environments.
